Article Title: YouTube gives four reasons with social media ban in Australia is ‘less safe’ for kids
Article Text:
4 reasons age bans are detrimental, according to YouTube



Poorly designed regulations make kids less safe:

Regulation fails to reflect platform differences:

Creative expression is worth preserving:

Evidence-based regulation is better:





As social media ban for under-16 in Australia is set to take effect on December 10, Google’s YouTube has voiced strong opposition to legislation, asserting that such blanket bans are likely to be “counterproductive” and ultimately make children less safe online. The platform’s stance comes as governments worldwide consider regulations to balance online safety with young people’s access to educational and creative material.“Last week we shared an update on what YouTube will look like for users and creators in Australia as a result of the new law. As other governments around the world consider how to tackle the very real challenge of helping young people stay safe online while also helping them access positive material, it's clear that blanket account bans will have extremely negative consequences,” YouTube said.YouTube outlined four specific reasons why this regulatory approach is flawed:YouTube argues that blanket bans remove choices from parents and force children out of curated, supervised spaces like YouTube Kids or supervised tween and teen accounts. According to the company, kids may resort to using adult accounts or browsing anonymously, often accessing less safe services.YouTube argues that applying blanket bans misunderstands the platform’s function, which is primarily a streaming service for learning, entertainment, news and sports highlights. YouTube noted that 94% of teachers globally use YouTube for educational content. Making it harder to promote educational content is counterproductive.The platform emphasised that YouTube offers young people digital skills, connection and opportunities for creative and political expression. The platform noted that some of the world’s biggest artists, including Justin Bieber and Dua Lipa, began their careers on YouTube as teenagers.YouTube also noted that a comprehensive approach that requires industry-wide standards for parental controls, limits access to specific risky features, mandates privacy-preserving age-estimation tools and bans personalised advertising to minors.
Article Summary: Social media ban for under-16 in Australia is set to take effect on December 10. Google’s YouTube has voiced strong opposition to legislation. The platform argues that blanket bans are likely to be ‘counterproductive’ and ultimately make children less safe online.

Article Title: JioHotsar to invest Rs 4,000 crore to acquire, produce content in South Indian languages
Article Text:
JioHotstar’s content strategy and competition







Reliance-Disney’s streaming service JioHotstar will make a massive investment of Rs 4,000 crore over the next five years, for acquiring and producing in several South Indian regional languages. The investment is framed as a broader collaboration with the Tamil Nadu government. Sushant Sreeram, Head – SVOD Business & Chief Marketing Officer at JioStar, confirmed that the platform formalised a Letter of Intent with the Government of Tamil Nadu."Earlier today, JioHotstar formalised a Letter of Intent with the Government of Tamil Nadu in the presence of the Chief Minister M K Stalin. This outlines a shared commitment to invest in talent, expand infrastructure and build a future-ready creative economy from the South,” he said, according to news agency PTI.“As part of this vision, JioHotstar will invest Rs 4,000 crore to nurture creators, strengthen the production ecosystem and build a pipeline of stories that are ready for India and ready for the world,” he added.South India is home to four major film industries producing content in Tamil, Telugu, Kannada and Malayalam. The investment will target new series and movies from the region, with a primary focus on acquiring films already released in cinemas.JioHotstar, which currently has over 200 million subscribers and competes with Amazon's Prime Video and Netflix in India, aims to more than double its subscriber count. The streaming platform noted that consumers in southern Indian states spend 70% more time on JioHotstar compared to other regions.Regarding market competition, Sushant Sreeram confirmed that JioHotstar’s partnership with Warner Bros will “continue till its end date,” though he did not disclose the specific date.
Article Summary: Reliance-Disney’s streaming service JioHotstar will make a massive investment of Rs 4,000 crore over the next five years. The investment is framed as a broader collaboration with the Tamil Nadu government. South India is home to four major film industries producing content in Tamil, Telugu, Kannada and Malayalam.

Article Title: Spotify takes on YouTube as it expands video access to US and Canada
Article Text:
Spotify app logo.

Spotify’s video catalogue







Spotify has announced that it is making music videos available to premium subscribers in the US and Canada. The expansion positions the Swedish streaming giant to directly challenge YouTube in the music video space. According to the company, video content offers a more immersive and engaging experience than audio alone, a factor that could help attract more users and advertisers. However, there will be a limited catalogue of music videos.Music videos will be available to all premium subscribers in the US and Canada by the end of the month. The launch follows a beta test conducted in nearly 100 markets last year and is intended to enhance Spotify's competitive position against music streaming offerings from rivals like Apple and Amazon.Spotify's initial video catalog will feature content from artists including Ariana Grande, Olivia Dean, BABYMONSTER, and Addison Rae. The company stated that fan engagement is boosted by the feature: “We've seen that when fans discover a track with a music video on Spotify, they're 34% more likely to stream it again and 24% more likely to save or share it in the following week.”Recently, CFO Christian Luiga highlighted the importance of this metric, noting that “Engagement is a very important part for sort of our measurement...sometimes, it could be an even more important than the number of users”.Meanwhile, the company recently launched Wrapped – its year-end roundup, which gained over 200 million engaged users within roughly 24 hours, marking a 19% increase from the previous year.The video expansion comes as Spotify looks to drive earnings growth through pricing adjustments. The company has already raised the cost of its premium individual plan in more than 150 markets during the September quarter. In a leadership shift, Spotify’s founder-CEO Daniel Ek will transition to the role of executive chairman in January.
Article Summary: Music videos will be available to all premium subscribers in the US and Canada by the end of the month. The launch follows a beta test conducted in nearly 100 markets last year. Spotify's initial video catalog will feature content from artists including Ariana Grande, Olivia Dean, BABYMONSTER, and Addison Rae.
